p: Adenosine analogs share the same mechanism of action which consists of impairing the function of viral RNA polymerase of several viruses such as measles and rabies [ 131]. One specific adenosine analog, NITD008, has been proven effective against a number of flaviviruses, raising the hypothesis that it would be a promising anti-ZIKV drug [ 98, 132]. NITD008 was able to decrease viral plaque forming units and diminish genome replication in culture lysates when added to Vero cells infected separately with two different strains of ZIKV [ 96, 97]. Previous reports had already indicated that NITD008 has good oral bioavailability and pharmacokinetic profile as well as low in vitro and only short-term in vitro toxicity [ 98]. Treatment of adult ZIKV-infected A129 mice with NITD008 (5 doses of 50 mg/kg i.p.) decreased mortality and blood viremia. Further investigation of its safety profile is needed before it is considered as an anti-ZIKV drug.
